deck: The Pinball Arcade provides a safe virtual home for your pinball worship, complete with accurate re-creations of real tables and appropriately realistic physics.

title: Bloodforge
deck: Bloodforge is the half-baked XBLA God of War clone you never asked for.

title: Mortal Kombat
deck: The Vita version of Mortal Kombat hits just as hard as its console counterparts.

title: Minecraft
deck: The Xbox version of Minecraft is both better and worse than the PC original, though it's most valuable for newcomers to the whole phenomenon.

title: Max Payne 3
deck: Rockstar Games modernizes and makes Max Payne its own, creating something grittier and more grounded in reality, if not quite as singular.

title: Diablo III
deck: The first Diablo game in over a decade is also one of the most insidiously satisfying loot treadmills in almost as long.

title: Game of Thrones
deck: There is probably a great role-playing game to be made out of George R.R. Martin's A Song of Ice and Fire novels, but Game of Thrones isn't it.

title: Prototype 2
deck: Prototype 2 gives you some interesting abilities that can be fun to use, but it doesn't give you enough good opportunities to cut loose with all that power.

title: Dragon's Dogma
deck: Capcom has delivered an open-world game with tremendously fun combat, a hilariously crazy ending, and not much else.

title: Tom Clancy's Ghost Recon: Future Soldier
deck: Ghost Recon Future Soldier has everything you'd expect from a modern shooter, but it doesn't really complete any of its tasks in an especially satisfying way.

title: Gravity Rush
deck: Though Gravity Rush's gravity shifting mechanic is genuinely awesome, the game itself doesn't offer enough interesting ways to use it.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization V: Gods & Kings
deck: Civ V's first real expansion is no revolution, but it's as good an excuse as any to take the plunge back into Firaxis' wonderfully addictive strategy game.

title: Steel Battalion: Heavy Armor
deck: If this is the best Kinect can do with a "hardcore" game, you should just pack it up and wait for the next Xbox.

title: LEGO Batman 2: DC Super Heroes
deck: Some of Lego Batman 2's new ideas work better than others, but at least this isn't just the same old Lego game.

title: Spec Ops: The Line
deck: Spec Ops: The Line is a mostly standard shooter with its share of rough edges, but it handles the subject matter of armed conflict in some extremely interesting ways.

title: Spelunky
deck: The Xbox Live Arcade update of Spelunky is as madly brilliant as it is maddeningly pitiless.

title: Theatrhythm Final Fantasy
deck: Tapping your way through the memorable Final Fantasy themes of the past two decades is more fun than you'd think.

title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim
deck: Skyrim's first DLC offers a broad array of quality new content that smoothly integrates into the game without feeling forced.

title: Tony Hawk's Pro Skater HD
deck: There are flashes of old brilliance in Tony Hawk's Pro Skater HD, but a lot of those moments are buried under questionable design decisions and a sterile feeling that leaves this downloadable release feeling a bit flat.

title: Deadlight
deck: The zombie-survival setting fits nicely with its deliberate style of 2D action, but Deadlight sometimes plays too fast and loose for its own good.

title: The Expendables 2
deck: The Expendables 2 somehow manages to turn the act of blowing anything and everything up into a dreadful bore.

title: Persona 4 Arena
deck: Whether you're interested in the Arc school of fighting game design or reading a Persona 4 visual novel set two months after the events of the real game, Persona 4 Arena has you covered.

title: Sound Shapes
deck: Both aesthetically and mechanically, Sound Shapes is an absolute delight.

title: Sleeping Dogs
deck: It's derivative as hell, but Sleeping Dogs' borrowed ideas are of a high enough quality to form an entertaining open-world experience.

title: Darksiders II
deck: Darksiders II builds upon the previous game in some really exciting ways, but even people who can't make that comparison will enjoy the weighty combat and multifaceted character development.

title: Papo & Yo
deck: Minority Media's debut game is at once a beautiful, affecting tale of childhood tragedy, and a generally lackluster puzzle platformer.

title: Hybrid
deck: Hybrid's less-is-more approach somehow makes shooting other players on an Xbox feel sort of new again.

title: Dust: An Elysian Tail
deck: Deep and involving mechanics, lavish, fluid artwork, and an emotionally resonant storyline--Dust pretty much has it all.

title: Transformers: Fall of Cybertron
deck: Fall of Cybertron has some truly excellent moments, but you'll need to look past some serious downsides to enjoy the overall package.

title: Rock Band Blitz
deck: Harmonix builds on its collective knowledge of rhythm games for a downloadable experience that offers something old and something new.

title: Madden NFL 13
deck: The ideas behind Madden NFL 13 are great ones. It's the execution that lets this year's installment down.

title: Tekken Tag Tournament 2
deck: Tekken Tag Tournament 2 works great online and offers enough variety to make it stand out from other recent Tekken efforts.

title: NHL 13
deck: On the ice, NHL 13 is the strongest sequel in the series to date. Off it? That's a bit more complicated...

title: Borderlands 2
deck: Borderlands 2 gives you more Borderlands. No more, no less.

title: Mark of the Ninja
deck: Mark of the Ninja is one of the most playable, rewarding, and downright fun stealth games ever made.

title: Fire Pro Wrestling
deck: Fire Pro Wrestling for XBLA is an inexplicable, almost likable fiasco.

title: Tokyo Jungle
deck: For a game that sounds like the setup for a bad SyFy film, Tokyo Jungle is a well-designed, supremely funny video game well worth your time.

title: Resident Evil 6
deck: Resident Evil 6 may be the most lavishly produced bad game in history.

title: Dishonored
deck: If you love yourself some Deus Ex, you're going to really like Dishonored, and if you've found the genre impenetrable in the past, I've got some good news for you.

title: NBA 2K13
deck: NBA 2K13 lacks the big, flashy hooks of its more recent predecessors, but it's still a pretty terrific basketball game all the same.

title: Fable: The Journey
deck: The Journey's heart is in the right place. It's too bad Kinect is the only way to play it.

title: Forza Horizon
deck: Plenty of racing games have tried to split the difference between simulation and "arcade" racing in the past, but there aren't many that do it as well as Forza Horizon.

title: XCOM: Enemy Unknown
deck: Firaxis honors the XCOM name with turn-based strategy that shepherds players as expertly as it punishes, confidently balancing the micro and the macro all the while.

title: 007 Legends
deck: Bland. Very bland.

title: Doom 3
deck: However you felt about Doom 3 when it came out, BFG Edition isn't the best way to play it today.

title: Medal of Honor: Warfighter
deck: Warfighter makes no successful effort to stand out in a very crowded genre.

title: Need for Speed: Most Wanted
deck: If you're looking for a multiplayer driving game that's about way more than simple races, Most Wanted's speedlist system makes for an amazingly good time.

title: WWE '13
deck: By looking backward, WWE '13 pushes this franchise forward in a shockingly positive way.

title: Halo 4
deck: The new developers behind the Halo franchise successfully emulate the style of their predecessors as a new trilogy begins with Halo 4.

title: Assassin's Creed III: Liberation
deck: Assassin's Creed III: Liberation tries to bring a console-quality blockbuster to a handheld with mixed results.

title: Hotline Miami
deck: Hotline Miami is a nightmare you won't want to forget.

title: Assassin's Creed III
deck: Assassin‚Äôs Creed III‚Äôs methodical world-building and wealth of clever gameplay systems are impressive, even if they don‚Äôt always confidently click together with all the other moving parts.

title: Call of Duty: Black Ops II
deck: The most dramatic changes in this year's Call of Duty come on the campaign side, with a story so full of choices big and small that you might not even be aware that you're making them.

title: Call of Duty: Black Ops Declassified
deck: You'd think that the people in charge of the Call of Duty franchise would be more protective of it than this.

title: New Super Mario Bros. U
deck: This is both a perfectly fine Wii U launch game, and a little too much "new" Super Mario a little too soon.

title: Nintendo Land
deck: If you want to find out exactly what that big new Wii U controller is good for, Nintendo Land is your best bet right now.

title: Hitman: Absolution
deck: Hitman: Absolution tries a few things differently than the games that came before it. Some don't work, but the ones that do are terrific.

title: ZombiU
deck: ZombiU is not a repeat of Red Steel. It's a smart, scary, incredibly difficult action game with an unfortunate name, an experience that rewards patience and punishes arrogance.

title: The Walking Dead
deck: The Walking Dead's first season is nothing short of a masterpiece of modern horror gaming.

title: PlayStation All-Stars Battle Royale
deck: This frantic fighting game just doesn't pack in enough PlayStation flavor to truly earn the title of "All-Star."

title: Adventure Time: Hey Ice King! Why‚Äôd you steal our garbage?!!
deck: Hey Ice King! is a game with its heart in the right place, but it's a bit too simple, and too fleeting to leave a lasting impression.

title: Far Cry 3
deck: Even when Far Cry 3's story eventually falls short of its promising start, you won't have as much fun hunting tigers, crashing hang gliders, and stabbing pirates in any other game.

title: Family Guy: Back to the Multiverse
deck: If you are a fundamentally terrible person on every imaginable level, then Family Guy: Back to the Multiverse is the video game for you.

title: DmC Devil May Cry
deck: The character action genre hasn't been this stylish or crazy in a good long while.

title: The Cave
deck: Ron Gilbert's lightweight morality play offers up some cleverness and challenge, but never completely coheres into a memorable whole.

title: Dead Space 3
deck: Dead Space 3 mixes some solid new ideas in with its stock horror-action tropes, but the overall quality of the production falls short of the series' standards.

title: Antichamber
deck: Antichamber's mindbending puzzles force you to learn the rules of an unfamiliar world and it makes for an exciting and thought-provoking time.

title: Aliens: Colonial Marines
deck: Both functionally broken and creatively bankrupt, Aliens: Colonial Marines is an extinction-level disaster.

title: Metal Gear Rising: Revengeance
deck: The points where the styles of Kojima Productions and PlatinumGames collide make playing Metal Gear Rising a short but enjoyable trip through a post-MGS4 world.

title: Tomb Raider
deck: Tomb Raider's tone is somewhat at odds with its action, but the reborn Lara Croft seems primed for a successful new adventuring career.

title: Crysis 3
deck: Crysis 3 looks great on the PC, but was this sequel really necessary?

title: SimCity
deck: SimCity offers up myriad tantalizing delights for the would-be city-builder, but encases them in an infrastructure that feels at odds with itself.

title: StarCraft II: Heart of the Swarm
deck: If you're still at all invested in keeping up with StarCraft II, there's no reason you shouldn't have Heart of the Swarm.

title: Gears of War: Judgment
deck: Judgment's campaign twists the Gears formula in some interesting ways, but the rest of the package feels pretty thin for a full-priced retail product.

title: The Walking Dead: Survival Instinct
deck: This is not the Walking Dead game you're looking for.

title: Luigi's Mansion: Dark Moon
deck: Dark Moon makes for a charming and challenging follow-up to Luigi's last GameCube adventure.

title: BioShock Infinite
deck: Infinite keeps the soul of BioShock at its core, but it isn't afraid to strike out in some very exciting new directions.

title: Guacamelee!
deck: DrinkBox Studios' lucha libre-flavored brawler is smartly designed, beautifully drawn, and just a lot of fun.

title: Injustice: Gods Among Us
deck: Injustice's unique fighting systems and wild super moves set it apart from the developer's previous work.

title: Dead Island Riptide
deck: Riptide is more Dead Island, but not better Dead Island.

title: Monaco: What's Yours Is Mine
deck: Monaco makes for a more compelling multiplayer romp than a single-player adventure, but its charms shine through any way you choose to play it.

title: Star Trek: The Video Game
deck: Set phasers to "shun."

title: Far Cry 3: Blood Dragon
deck: Blood Dragon has a terrific sense of style and gives you some good extra Far Cry 3-style gameplay to fool around with.

title: Metro: Last Light
deck: 4A Games makes impressive strides in improving Metro's core gameplay without losing the pieces that made the original so special.

title: Fuse
deck: Insomniac's trademark creative weaponry gives a little extra oomph to Fuse's otherwise by-the-numbers third-person shooting.

title: Remember Me
deck: Remember Me is an elegant premise executed problematically.

title: The Last of Us
deck: Naughty Dog throws out its own rule book and challenges players to survive a harrowing but thrilling journey through a world forever changed by death and destruction.

title: Deadpool
deck: The Merc with the Mouth is accurately realized in this otherwise clunky action game, though that might be more curse than blessing.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization V: Brave New World
deck: "Brave" isn't the right word for this last Civ V expansion, but it sure does offer up a lot of smart changes and upgrades.

title: Shadowrun Returns
deck: You don't have to know a lick about Shadowrun to enjoy this deliciously weird, if flawed, strategy game.

title: Gone Home
deck: This house has a story to tell, and players patient enough to listen will be rewarded with a touching story that won't soon leave you.

title: Saints Row IV
deck: Saints Row IV builds on the style and sense of humor of the previous game really well, even if it leans a little too heavily on its predecessor at times.

title: Pikmin 3
deck: Pikmin 3 might just be the most pleasingly balanced entry in the franchise yet.

title: The Bureau: XCOM Declassified
deck: An entertaining combat system props up this otherwise clunky, harebrained sci-fi action game.
